The high-intensity landing lights are designed to illuminate the runway environment during approach and landing, providing sufficient visibility for the pilot to identify the touchdown zone and runway edges.

15LTS23.explanation: For cargo compartment lighting, when the respective light switch is ON, the cargo compartment lights illuminate to allow ground personnel to load and unload cargo safely. These lights are typically controlled from the flight deck or from a switch panel accessible from the cargo door area.

15LTS24.explanation: For exterior lighting, after selecting any service or maintenance light switch on the exterior lights panel, the corresponding service lights illuminate the aircraft exterior. These include wing inspection lights, logo lights, and service lights that help ground personnel during nighttime operations, fueling, and maintenance activities.

08ELD23.explanation: In the A220 display reversion logic, when DU 1 (which normally displays the Captain's PFD) fails, the Primary Flight Display automatically reverts to DU 2 (the center display unit). This is part of the Pro Line Fusion avionics system's redundancy architecture, which ensures that critical flight information remains available to the flight crew even during display failures. The A220 has five interchangeable display units (DU 1-5), and the system is designed to automatically reconfigure displays to maintain the most critical flight information on available screens. DU 2, being centrally located, provides the best backup position for the Captain's PFD as it remains easily visible to both pilots.

sources.page: Pro Line Fusion - Display Unit Failure Procedures

08ELD06.explanation: The slip/skid indicator (also known as the ball or inclinometer) provides yaw indication on the Primary Flight Display. This indicator shows whether the aircraft is in coordinated flight or if there is a sideslip condition. When the aircraft yaws left or right without proper coordinated rudder input, the slip/skid indicator will move off-center, indicating uncoordinated flight. The roll pointer indicates bank angle, the pitch target marker shows autopilot pitch commands, and the aircraft reference symbol represents the aircraft's position relative to the horizon. Only the slip/skid indicator specifically measures and displays yaw - the rotation of the aircraft around its vertical axis.

sources.page: Electronic Display - Primary Flight Display Symbology
Flight Instruments - Attitude and Slip/Skid Indicators

08ELD28.explanation: The Integrated Standby Instrument (ISI) on the A220 normally receives its air data from ADSP 3. When ADSP 3 fails, the system automatically switches to ADSP 4 as the backup air data source. The A220 is equipped with four Air Data Smart Probes (ADSPs) that provide redundancy for critical air data measurements including airspeed, altitude, angle of attack, and static/dynamic pressure. The ISI is a critical backup instrument designed to continue providing essential flight information (airspeed, altitude, attitude) even when primary display systems fail. The automatic switching from ADSP 3 to ADSP 4 ensures continuous, reliable air data to this backup instrument without crew intervention.

sources.page: Electronic Display - Air Data System Architecture

08ELD01.explanation: The A220 cockpit features three main control panels for interacting with the Pro Line Fusion avionics: (1) The Cursor Control Panel (CCP) contains trackball/cursor controls for navigating display menus and selecting items on screen, (2) The Multifunction Keyboard Panel (MKP) provides alphanumeric data entry capabilities for inputting flight plans, waypoints, and other text-based information, and (3) The Control Tuning Panel (CTP) contains rotary knobs for tuning radio frequencies and making numerical adjustments. These panels are strategically positioned on the center pedestal to be accessible to both pilots and provide intuitive control of the flight management and communication systems.

08ELD13.explanation: This statement is TRUE. The Air Data Smart Probes (ADSPs) on the A220 are multifunctional sensors that measure multiple air data parameters including angle of attack (AOA). Each ADSP measures static pressure, pitot pressure (dynamic pressure), and angle of attack using differential pressure sensors. The angle of attack is derived from differential pressure measured through two holes symmetrically placed on the upper and lower surfaces of the probe's truncated cone. In addition to the four ADSPs, the A220 also has two separate dedicated AOA vanes for additional redundancy. Angle of attack information is critical for stall protection, flight envelope protection, and optimal aircraft performance.

sources.page: Electronic Display - Air Data System Components
Air Data Smart Probes - AOA Measurement

08ELD03.explanation: This statement is TRUE. The reversion switch panel includes L (Left) and R (Right) CURSOR INHIB pushbuttons that allow pilots to disable a malfunctioning cursor control. When pressed, the associated cursor is inhibited (disabled), and a green light illuminates to indicate the inhibit is active. This feature is important in situations where a cursor becomes erratic or stuck, which could interfere with flight operations. By inhibiting the faulty cursor, the crew can continue using the other cursor control panel without interference. The green light provides clear visual confirmation that the cursor inhibit function is engaged.

08ELD11.question: Identify the type of EICAS message shown for each of the following.
08ELD11.answerText: Multiple selection question with image reference
08ELD11.explanation: This is a visual identification question requiring pilots to recognize different EICAS message types by their color and format. The A220 EICAS system uses a color-coded hierarchy for messages: WARNING messages appear in RED and require immediate crew action, often accompanied by master warning lights and triple chimes; CAUTION messages appear in AMBER and require immediate crew awareness with single chimes; ADVISORY messages appear in CYAN and require crew awareness but are less time-critical; STATUS messages appear in WHITE indicating non-normal but non-threatening conditions; and INFO messages appear on the bottom bar. The ability to quickly identify message types by color and format is critical for proper prioritization of crew actions during abnormal situations. Messages are displayed in priority order (Warning/Caution/Advisory/Status) with newest messages of each type appearing first.
references: A220 FCOM - EICAS Message Types and Colors

08ELD25.explanation: The Flight Path Vector (FPV) can display in different modes on the A220 PFD. In CAGED MODE, the FPV's lateral drift component is removed, showing only the vertical flight path angle. This mode is useful for determining angle of attack more precisely by eliminating the drift indication. In normal (conformal) mode, the FPV shows both vertical and lateral flight path, moving anywhere on the display to indicate the actual direction of aircraft movement. In NON-CONFORMAL mode, the FPV may be displayed with reduced accuracy when certain data is invalid. The caged mode helps pilots focus on pitch performance without the distraction of lateral drift, particularly useful during approaches or when assessing angle of attack margins.

sources.page: Electronic Display - PFD Symbology Flight Path Vector Modes

08ELD09.explanation: The EICAS (Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting System) displays two primary categories of information: (a) Configuration and trim indications - including flap position, slat position, landing gear status, spoiler position, and horizontal stabilizer trim position, and (d) Engine and fuel quantity indications - including N1, N2, EGT (Exhaust Gas Temperature), fuel flow, oil pressure/temperature, and total fuel quantity. The EICAS does NOT display VHF COM frequencies (these appear on the Radio Tuning Unit displays) or a list of synoptic pages (synoptic pages are accessed through multifunction displays but the list is not on EICAS).

sources.page: Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting System

08ELD07.explanation: The speed error tape is a vertical tape indicator on the PFD that shows the difference between the current airspeed and the autopilot or autothrottle target speed. It appears as a magenta tape extending from the current airspeed indicator, with tick marks showing incremental speed differences. When the tape extends upward, it indicates the target speed is higher than current speed (aircraft needs to accelerate). When it extends downward, the target speed is lower (aircraft needs to decelerate). This is different from the airspeed tape (which shows actual indicated airspeed), the flight path vector (which shows actual flight path direction), and the flight path acceleration cue.

sources.page: Speed Error Tape - Function and Display

08ELD27.explanation: Each tick mark on the speed error tape represents 5 knots of difference between the current airspeed and the target/selected speed. The speed error tape provides a quick visual reference for how far the aircraft's current speed deviates from the autopilot or autothrottle target. The 5-knot increment is a standardized value that provides good resolution for speed monitoring without cluttering the display with too many marks. Pilots can instantly see the magnitude of speed error by counting tick marks. This is particularly useful during approaches when precise speed control is critical, or when monitoring autopilot/autothrottle performance to ensure the automation is properly managing the aircraft's energy state.

sources.page: Electronic Display - Speed Error Tape Scaling

08ELD22.explanation: Mach number displays on the Primary Flight Display (PFD) under the airspeed tape when the aircraft's speed exceeds 0.45 Mach. Below this threshold, Mach number is not displayed because it is not operationally relevant at lower speeds where indicated airspeed is the primary speed reference. At higher altitudes and speeds, Mach number becomes more important than indicated airspeed due to compressibility effects on the airframe and the proximity to maximum operating Mach (MMO). The automatic display of Mach above 0.45M ensures pilots have the critical speed reference information appropriate for their flight regime. The 0.45M threshold represents the transition point where Mach number monitoring becomes operationally significant.

sources.page: Electronic Display - Mach Number Display Logic

08ELD14.question: Match the function of each air data system probe (ADSP).
08ELD14.explanation: The A220 has four Air Data Smart Probes (ADSPs), each providing redundant air data measurements. Each ADSP measures: Static pressure (for altitude and vertical speed calculations), Pitot/dynamic pressure (for airspeed calculations), and Angle of attack (for stall protection and flight envelope protection). The four ADSPs provide quadruple redundancy for critical air data, with the system able to cross-check between probes to detect failures or discrepancies. Additionally, the aircraft has two separate AOA vanes and two Total Air Temperature (TAT) probes for further redundancy. This matching question tests understanding of which ADSP feeds which system (e.g., Captain's instruments vs First Officer's instruments, autopilot systems, Integrated Standby Instrument). The redundancy architecture ensures that failure of any single ADSP does not compromise flight safety or the availability of critical air data.

08ELD26.explanation: When Display Unit 1 (DU 1), which normally displays the Captain's Primary Flight Display, fails, the PFD automatically reverts to DU 2 (the center display unit). This automatic reversion is part of the A220's Pro Line Fusion display management system. The reversion logic is designed to maintain critical flight instrumentation on available displays without crew intervention. DU 2 is selected as the reversion target because of its central location, making it visible to both pilots. The system prioritizes displaying PFDs (most critical information) over other display formats during multiple display failures. The automatic nature of this reversion reduces pilot workload during abnormal situations.

sources.page: Electronic Display - Pro Line Fusion Display Reversion Logic

08ELD17.explanation: When there is a disagreement of more than 4 degrees between the pitch or bank angle indications on the Captain's and First Officer's PFDs, an ATT DIFF (Attitude Difference) indication appears. This alert warns the crew that the two Inertial Reference Units (IRUs) or Air Data and Inertial Reference Systems (ADIRS) are providing conflicting attitude information. Such a discrepancy could indicate a failure in one of the attitude sources or a problem with one IRU. The 4-degree threshold is set to detect significant errors while avoiding nuisance alerts from minor computational differences. When this indication appears, pilots must cross-reference their attitude indicators and potentially use the Integrated Standby Instrument (ISI).

08ELD16.explanation: The A220 air data system comprises: (a) Two angle-of-attack (AOA) vanes - dedicated sensors mounted on the forward fuselage that provide redundant AOA measurement independent of the ADSPs, (b) Two total air temperature (TAT) probes - measure outside air temperature accounting for compressibility heating, essential for performance calculations and engine control, and (d) Four air data system probes (ADSPs) - multifunctional smart probes that measure static pressure, pitot pressure, and angle of attack. The system does NOT include three pitot tubes - the pitot pressure measurement is integrated into the four ADSPs rather than using separate pitot tubes.

sources.page: Electronic Display - Air Data System Configuration

08ELD04.explanation: The normal configuration of the A220's five display units is: DU 1 (Captain's PFD on the left), DU 2 (MFD/center display showing navigation and systems), DU 3 (EICAS in the center-lower position showing engine parameters and crew alerts), DU 4 (MFD/center display on the First Officer's side), and DU 5 (First Officer's PFD on the right). This five-display layout is part of the Rockwell Collins Pro Line Fusion avionics suite. The displays are all 15.1-inch high-resolution LCDs that are interchangeable, meaning any display can show any format if needed during reversion situations.

sources.page: Pro Line Fusion - Normal Display Layout

08ELD08.explanation: The airspeed trend vector (also called the speed trend arrow) displays the predicted airspeed 10 seconds in the future based on the current rate of acceleration or deceleration. This predictive indicator appears as a vertical line extending from the current airspeed indication on the speed tape. If the aircraft is accelerating, the trend vector points upward, showing where the speed will be in 10 seconds if the current acceleration continues. If decelerating, it points downward. The 10-second prediction window is optimal for pilot situational awareness - it's long enough to provide useful advance warning of speed trends but short enough to remain accurate despite changing flight conditions.

08ELD21.explanation: Each tick mark on the speed error tape represents a difference of 5 knots between the current airspeed and the target/selected speed. The speed error tape provides a quick visual reference for how far the aircraft's current speed deviates from the autopilot or autothrottle target. The 5-knot increment is a standardized value that provides good resolution for speed monitoring without cluttering the display with too many marks. Pilots can instantly see the magnitude of speed error by counting tick marks: one tick = 5 knots error, two ticks = 10 knots error, etc. This is particularly useful during approaches when precise speed control is critical.

sources.page: Electronic Display - Speed Error Tape Scaling

08ELD20.explanation: This statement is TRUE. On the A220 PFD, when Mach number is displayed (above 0.45M), the True Airspeed (TAS) and Ground Speed (GS) are shown below the Mach number readout. This grouping of related speed parameters provides comprehensive speed information in one area of the display. True Airspeed (TAS) is the actual speed of the aircraft through the air mass, corrected for altitude and temperature. Ground Speed (GS) is the speed over the ground, incorporating wind effects. By displaying TAS and GS together with Mach number at higher speeds/altitudes, pilots have all relevant speed references visible simultaneously.

sources.page: Electronic Display - PFD Speed Display Format

08ELD24.explanation: The EICAS rotary switch controls how information is distributed across the display units. When set to SWAP position, the EICAS display (normally on DU 3) swaps positions with one of the MFD displays. This might be done to provide better visibility of EICAS information or to accommodate personal preferences or specific operational needs. The other positions are: NORM (normal configuration with EICAS on DU 3), ALTN (alternate configuration moving EICAS to a different display), and REV (reversion mode used during display failures). Understanding display configuration and the ability to recognize which switch position creates which display arrangement is important for both normal operations and abnormal situations.

08ELD19.explanation: This statement is FALSE. The top of the low speed marker (also called the barber pole or stall warning speed reference) does NOT correspond to the sidestick hard stop speed (VAOA HARD). Instead, the low speed marker indicates a speed range approaching stall speed, with the top typically representing stick shaker speed or another stall warning threshold. The VAOA HARD is the speed at which the sidestick hard stop protection activates in the fly-by-wire system - when the aircraft approaches this critical angle of attack, the flight control system prevents further aft sidestick movement to protect against stall. These are related but distinct speeds in the flight envelope protection system.

08ELD05.explanation: This statement is TRUE. A non-conformal FPV is displayed when the system cannot accurately position the FPV in its normal conformal mode, typically due to invalid or unreliable data from the inertial reference system or air data system. In normal conformal mode, the FPV is precisely positioned on the display to show the exact direction of aircraft movement relative to the horizon and attitude indicator. In non-conformal mode, the FPV may be displayed with reduced accuracy or in a fixed position with an indication that its accuracy is degraded. Visual cues that indicate non-conformal mode typically include color changes (such as amber instead of green), different symbology, or accompanying text messages.

sources.page: Electronic Display - Flight Path Vector Modes

08ELD18.explanation: The EICAS message inhibit function suppresses certain non-critical alerts during takeoff to reduce pilot workload during this high-task-load phase of flight. The message inhibit ends at 400 feet AGL (Above Ground Level) during takeoff. Below 400 feet AGL after liftoff, only critical warnings are displayed - cautions and advisories that are not immediately flight-safety critical are inhibited (suppressed). Once the aircraft climbs through 400 feet AGL, the inhibit is removed and all previously suppressed messages are displayed. This altitude threshold represents a point where the aircraft is safely airborne with sufficient altitude for the crew to deal with non-critical issues.

sources.page: Electronic Display - EICAS Message Inhibit Logic
Crew Alerting System - Phase of Flight Filtering

08ELD10.explanation: When a WARNING message (red text) appears on the EICAS, two key indications occur: (b) A triple chime sounds - this is the distinctive aural alert for warning-level messages, immediately capturing crew attention even if they are not actively scanning the EICAS display, and (d) WARNING flashes on both master WARNING/CAUTION switch/lights - the master warning lights on the glareshield in front of both pilots flash to provide a clear visual alert that requires acknowledgment. The combination of visual (flashing lights, red text) and aural (triple chime) alerts ensures warnings cannot be missed.

08ELD02.explanation: The primary method for moving cursors on the A220 displays is using the trackball or cursor control device on the Cursor Control Panel (CCP). However, if the trackball fails or is unavailable, the alternate control method is to use the arrow keys on the Multifunction Keyboard Panels (MKPs). The MKPs, located on the center pedestal, have dedicated arrow keys (up, down, left, right) that can move the cursor in the same way as the trackball. This redundancy ensures that even if the CCP trackball malfunctions, pilots can still navigate through FMS pages, select items on displays, and interact with the avionics systems.

07ELE11.explanation: When no AC power is available and the battery switches are selected to AUTO, the batteries automatically connect to power all three DC ESS BUSES (DC ESS BUS 1, 2, and 3). This ensures critical DC electrical systems remain powered during AC power loss. The batteries provide backup power to essential systems until AC power is restored or the RAT is deployed.

07ELE22.explanation: The engine Variable Frequency Generators (VFGs) have a self-contained oil system for cooling and lubrication. This independent oil system is separate from the engine oil system, ensuring proper generator operation and longevity. The self-contained system eliminates dependency on engine lubrication.

07ELE06.explanation: Both conventional Thermal Circuit Breakers (TCBs) and Electronic Circuit Breakers (ECBs) status are displayed on the CB (Circuit Breaker) synoptic page. This allows pilots to monitor the status of all circuit protection devices from a single display, improving situational awareness and troubleshooting capability.

07ELE15.explanation: The engine Variable Frequency Generators (VFGs) are rated at 75 kVA each. Note that kVA (kilovolt-amperes) is a measure of apparent power, not voltage (VAC). Each VFG provides 115 VAC variable frequency power, but the power rating is 75 kVA, making them the primary AC power sources for the aircraft.

07ELE08.explanation: This statement is true. During engine starts using APU bleed air, the APU Electronic Control Unit (ECU) may automatically request electrical load shedding to ensure sufficient pneumatic pressure is available for the engine starter. This prioritizes pneumatic power over electrical loads during the critical start sequence.
07ELE08.page: APU System - Engine Start Operations section

07ELE23.explanation: The EXT PWR (External Power) switch/light on the ELECTRICAL panel is used to connect and disconnect external AC power to/from the aircraft electrical system. When pushed, it commands the external power contactor to close or open, allowing ground power to supply the aircraft buses when suitable external power is available.

07ELE02.explanation: The red EMER PWR ONLY message displays on EICAS when there is complete AC power loss AND both conditions occur: the RAT is deployed (providing emergency AC power) and the batteries are supplying their respective DC ESS BUSES. This indicates the aircraft is operating on emergency power only, with the RAT providing AC power and batteries providing DC power.

07ELE16.explanation: The Ram Air Turbine (RAT) deploys automatically in case of complete loss of in-flight AC power, ensuring emergency electrical and hydraulic power. It can also be deployed manually by pressing the guarded RAT GEN light/switch on the electrical panel. The RAT does NOT deploy for single engine or APU failures alone, only for complete AC power loss.

07ELE07.explanation: On the ELEC synoptic page, the DC EMER bus displays only in a fault condition (when it's being powered abnormally), and the BATT DIR BUSES never display under normal or fault conditions. These buses are not shown during normal operations to reduce display clutter, as they are only used in specific emergency electrical configurations.

07ELE05.explanation: On the CB synoptic page, selecting the TRIP acknowledgment soft key performs three functions: it confirms the breaker tripped state, removes the CB TRIP message from EICAS if no other trip acknowledgements are active, and changes the breaker state to OUT. It does NOT reset the breaker - that would require physical intervention or system reset.
07ELE05.page: Electrical System - Circuit Breaker Management section

07ELE10.explanation: The guarded L DISC and R DISC switches perform mechanical disconnection of the VFG from the engine gearbox when pressed. The white DISC light illuminates in the switch to indicate that the associated generator is disconnected from the engine gearbox. This is a mechanical disconnect used when generator faults require isolation from the engine.

07ELE13.explanation: This is true. The A220 electrical system uses 115 VAC (volts alternating current) for AC power and 28 VDC (volts direct current) for DC power. These are standard aircraft electrical power specifications, with AC power provided by generators and DC power provided by batteries or converted from AC through TRUs (Transformer Rectifier Units).

07ELE03.explanation: In the event of complete AC power loss, the RAT deploys automatically, supplies electrical power at aircraft speeds of 148 KIAS and above (below this speed it may not generate sufficient power), and provides emergency AC power and hydraulics. The RAT does NOT retract automatically - it must be manually retracted on the ground after landing.

07ELE20.explanation: The two PMAGs (Permanent Magnet Alternator Generators) provide dedicated power to the Fly-By-Wire Power Converters (FBWPCs) and the Full Authority Digital Engine Controls (FADECs). These are critical flight control and engine control systems that require highly reliable, independent power sources. Each PMAG is engine-driven and provides power regardless of the main electrical system status.

07ELE14.explanation: Once the RAT is deployed, even if one or both engine VFGs are recovered and provide power to the main AC buses, the RAT GEN continues to supply the AC ESS BUS and DC ESS BUS 3. This ensures continuous power to essential systems and prevents power interruptions during electrical system reconfigurations following the initial power loss event.

07ELE19.explanation: When the RAT GEN guarded switch is pushed while the RAT is deployed, it resets the RAT GCU (Generator Control Unit). This can be used to attempt recovery from a RAT generator fault condition. The RAT itself remains deployed and spinning, but the GCU is reset to try to restore generator output. The RAT cannot be stowed in flight.

07ELE12.explanation: The APU GEN FAIL light illuminates amber when the APU generator disconnects from the aircraft electrical system due to a fault condition. The OFF light illuminates when the APU generator is selected off (manually disconnected) while the APU is running. These two indications differentiate between automatic fault disconnection and manual crew disconnection.

07ELE18.explanation: When external power is connected and suitable in terms of frequency, voltage, and phase (meeting all quality parameters), an EXT PWR AVAIL advisory message displays on the EICAS. This informs the crew that suitable external power is available to be connected to the aircraft electrical system by pressing the EXT PWR switch.

07ELE09.explanation: On the ELECTRICAL panel EXT PWR switch, the AVAIL light illuminates green when suitable external AC power is available to the aircraft (power is connected and meets quality parameters). The IN USE light illuminates when external power is actually being used to supply the aircraft electrical buses. These two lights distinguish between power availability and actual usage.
07ELE09.page: Electrical System - External Power Panel section

07ELE21.explanation: The DC EMER (Emergency) bus displays on the ELEC synoptic page only in a fault condition. During normal operations, this bus is not shown on the display to reduce clutter. It only appears when abnormal electrical configurations result in the DC EMER bus being powered, indicating a non-normal electrical system state that requires crew awareness.

07ELE17.explanation: The circuit breaker (CB) synoptic page offers four sort selections for displaying CB information: STATUS (sort by tripped/normal state), BUS (sort by which electrical bus), SYSTEM (sort by aircraft system/ATA chapter), and LOCATION (sort by physical location in aircraft). These sorting options help crew quickly find specific circuit breakers during troubleshooting.

07ELE04.explanation: When external power is suitable in terms of frequency, voltage, and phase (meeting all quality requirements), a green AVAIL light illuminates on the EXT PWR switch/light on the ELECTRICAL panel. This indicates that external power is available and ready to be connected by pressing the switch. The AVAIL indication confirms power quality before connection.
07ELE04.page: Electrical System - External Power Controls section

07ELE01.explanation: The Transformer Rectifier Units (TRUs) convert 115 VAC (alternating current) power to 28 VDC (direct current) power. There are three TRUs in the A220 electrical system that supply the DC buses from the AC power sources. This conversion is essential because many aircraft systems require DC power, while the primary generators produce AC power.

PERF01.explanation: Maximum Planned Takeoff Weight (PTOW) calculation considers several factors: runway length, runway slope, elevation, temperature, pressure altitude, obstacle clearance requirements, and aircraft configuration. The PTOW is the most restrictive weight from field length limiting weight, climb limiting weight, obstacle limiting weight, and brake energy limiting weight. Use the A220 Performance section in QRH or flight planning software to calculate the specific PTOW for given conditions.

PERF02.explanation: The optimum flap setting for takeoff is determined by balancing takeoff performance requirements with obstacle clearance needs. Lower flap settings (Flap 1 or 2) provide better climb performance but require longer runway. Higher flap settings (Flap 3 or 4) reduce takeoff distance but decrease climb gradient. The optimum setting depends on runway available, obstacles in the departure path, and aircraft weight. Performance calculations in the QRH or OPT determine the best flap setting.

PERF03.explanation: When approach ATIS reports 'Damp' runway conditions, performance calculations must account for reduced braking action. For the A220, damp runway conditions require using the appropriate performance factors from the Landing Performance section. Damp conditions typically result in approximately 10-15% increase in landing distance compared to dry runway. Autobrake selection and approach speed adjustments may be required.

PERF04.explanation: When 50% of the runway is covered with standing water (or contamination), landing performance must be recalculated using the contaminated runway performance data. Standing water significantly reduces braking effectiveness. The required landing distance increases substantially, and the crew must verify that the available runway length provides adequate margin. Aquaplaning speeds must also be considered.

PERF05.explanation: Similar to PERF04, when 50% of the runway is reported covered with contamination (snow, slush, or ice), specific contaminated runway performance corrections must be applied. The type and depth of contamination significantly affects braking and directional control. Use the contaminated runway performance section of the QRH to determine landing distance requirements and maximum crosswind limits.

PERF06.explanation: When the aircraft has multiple unrelated failures including L ENG FAIL, performance must be recalculated for single-engine operations and any additional system degradation. Each failure may have cumulative effects on approach speed, landing distance, and go-around performance. Consult the QRH for specific performance corrections for the combination of failures.

PERF07.explanation: Following an inflight engine fire that has been addressed using the L ENG FIRE procedure, single-engine landing performance must be applied. The affected engine is secured and unavailable, requiring use of single-engine approach speed corrections, increased landing distance, and single-engine go-around performance if required. The fire suppression system status may also affect cargo fire protection.

PERF08.explanation: Aircraft landing performance shall be verified against the actual landing distance required (LDR) compared to the landing distance available (LDA). Before landing, crews must ensure that LDA exceeds LDR with appropriate safety factors. For contaminated runways, the factored landing distance must not exceed the available runway length. Performance verification should consider current aircraft weight and configuration.

PERF09.explanation: For an A220 approaching EVRA for a Flap 5 landing on RWY36, the crew must verify landing performance for the specific conditions. Flap 5 landing configuration provides good landing performance with acceptable approach speed and landing distance. The runway conditions, wind, and aircraft weight must be checked against the performance tables to ensure safe landing margins.

PERF10.explanation: The QRH Ice Disposal Procedure contains specific steps for removing ice contamination from the aircraft. These typically include: applying approved de-icing fluid, inspecting critical surfaces for ice, ensuring all control surfaces move freely, checking pitot/static systems, and verifying engine inlet areas are clear. Ground de-icing must be completed within the holdover time limits.

PERF11.explanation: For aircraft YL-CSE approaching EVRA RWY36 with the given ATIS conditions, landing performance must be calculated using current reported conditions. The ATIS provides essential information including wind, visibility, ceiling, temperature, altimeter setting, and runway condition. All these factors affect the required landing distance and approach speed.

PERF12.explanation: For aircraft YL-CSE approaching EVRA RWY36 with engaged autopilot, minimum autopilot engagement heights and approach category limitations apply. The autopilot can be used down to the minimum engagement height (typically 400 ft for non-precision approaches, lower for CAT II/III). Performance calculations with autopilot engaged remain the same as manual flight; only the minimum engagement altitude is affected.

04APU07.explanation: When the APU rotary switch is positioned to OFF, the Electronic Control Unit (ECU) does NOT shut down the APU immediately. Instead, it initiates a 60-second cooldown period to allow the APU to cool down properly, especially if it was providing bleed air. During this cooldown, the APU continues to run at idle speed. After the cooldown period completes and the APU shuts down, the inlet door then closes automatically. This controlled shutdown sequence protects the APU from thermal stress.
04APU07.source: FCOM1 - APU System, SmartCockpit A220 APU Documentation

04APU11.explanation: An APU start requires either TRU 3 (Transformer Rectifier Unit 3) when AC power is available, OR both batteries when no AC power is available. TRU 3 converts AC power to DC power needed for the APU start sequence. When using batteries, both batteries work together - Battery 1 powers the ECU while Battery 2 powers the APU starter motor. TRU 2 is not used for APU starts, and Battery 2 alone is insufficient.
04APU11.source: FCOM1 - APU System, SmartCockpit A220 APU Documentation
04APU11.page: APU Operations - Power Requirements for Starting

04APU09.explanation: This statement is TRUE. The Electronic Control Unit (ECU) provides complete automated control of the APU from start through shutdown. The ECU is certified for unattended operation on the ground, meaning the APU can operate safely without crew supervision while on the ground. The ECU monitors all critical parameters (temperature, pressure, speed, etc.) and will automatically shut down the APU if any fault conditions occur, ensuring safe operation even when unattended.
04APU09.source: FCOM1 - APU System, SmartCockpit A220 APU Documentation
04APU09.page: APU System - ECU Control and Certification

04APU16.explanation: The APU provides an alternate source of AC electrical power at 3 phase, 400 Hz, 115 VAC. This is the standard aircraft electrical specification used in commercial aviation. The 3-phase configuration provides more efficient power distribution, 400 Hz frequency (instead of 50/60 Hz ground power) allows smaller and lighter transformers and components (critical for aircraft weight), and 115 VAC is the standard aircraft voltage. The APU generator is variable frequency during start but stabilizes at 400 Hz once running.
04APU16.source: FCOM1 - APU System, Aircraft Electrical Power Standards
04APU16.page: APU System - Electrical Power Generation Specifications

04APU18.explanation: During the APU start sequence, when the RPM reaches above 70% (typically around 95-99% plus a 2-second stabilization), the 'APU ON' status message appears on EICAS (Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting System). This indicates the APU has successfully completed its start cycle and is now running normally. At lower speeds (around 40-60% RPM), the white START light extinguishes, but the APU ON message only appears once the APU reaches operational speed above 70%.
04APU18.source: FCOM1 - APU System, SmartCockpit A220 APU Documentation

04APU01.explanation: The APU inlet door position is controlled by the Electronic Control Unit (ECU). The ECU determines the optimal door position (fully open, intermediate, or fully closed) based on multiple inputs including weight-on-wheels signal, Mach number, Total Air Temperature (TAT), and Air Data System (ADS) information. On the ground, the door typically opens fully, while in flight it may modulate to an intermediate position to optimize airflow. The ECU automatically manages door position without pilot input.
04APU01.source: FCOM1 - APU System, SmartCockpit A220 APU Documentation

04APU05.explanation: In flight, the ECU initiates an automatic shutdown ONLY when a critical ECU fault occurs (such as loss of DC power to the ECU). Other conditions like low oil pressure, high oil temperature, or uncommanded door position do NOT cause automatic shutdown in flight - they only trigger warnings. This is because shutting down the APU in flight could eliminate a critical backup power source. On the ground, more conditions will trigger automatic shutdown. Even an APU fire does not cause automatic shutdown in flight (ground only).
04APU05.source: FCOM1 - APU System, SmartCockpit A220 APU Documentation
04APU05.page: APU System - Automatic Shutdown Logic (Flight vs Ground)

04APU12.explanation: APU start restrictions are: Maximum 3 start attempts with 2 minutes of cooling between each start attempt. After 3 attempts, you must wait 1 hour before attempting additional starts. This limitation protects the APU starter motor from overheating and prevents damage to the APU during repeated start attempts. The cooling periods allow the starter motor and APU components to cool down adequately. These restrictions are critical for maintaining APU reliability and preventing component damage.
04APU12.source: FCOM1 - APU System Limitations, Operations Manual Part B A220

04APU15.explanation: If a high oil temperature condition occurs while the aircraft is IN FLIGHT, the APU remains in operation. This is a critical design feature - the APU will NOT shut down automatically for high oil temperature in flight because it may be providing essential backup electrical power or bleed air. A caution message will display alerting the crew, but the APU continues to run. On the ground, the same condition would cause an automatic shutdown. This flight vs ground logic prioritizes maintaining power availability during flight operations.
04APU15.source: FCOM1 - APU System, SmartCockpit A220 APU Documentation
04APU15.page: APU System - High Oil Temperature Logic (Flight Protection)

04APU10.explanation: Fuel is supplied to the APU by three possible sources: (1) Either left OR right AC boost pump when AC power is available - not just the left pump, (2) Suction feed if no AC power is available or the left engine is not operating - the APU's fuel control unit creates suction to draw fuel, (3) The left engine main ejector pump when the left engine is operating - this provides fuel pressure from engine operation. These three methods ensure the APU has fuel supply in all operating conditions.
04APU10.source: FCOM1 - APU System, SmartCockpit A220 APU Documentation

04APU08.explanation: The main purpose of the APU is to provide an alternate source of AC electrical power AND bleed air during ground and flight operations. The APU does NOT directly provide DC power - it provides AC power, which is then converted to DC by the aircraft's Transformer Rectifier Units (TRUs). The APU's two primary functions are: (1) supplying 3-phase AC electrical power (115 VAC, 400 Hz) to the aircraft electrical system, and (2) providing pneumatic bleed air for air conditioning, pressurization, and engine starting.
04APU08.source: FCOM1 - APU System, SmartCockpit A220 APU Documentation
04APU08.page: APU System - Primary Functions and Purpose

04APU02.explanation: The APU air inlet door position AND APU performance parameters (such as RPM and exhaust gas temperature/EGT) are displayed on the STATUS synoptic page. This dedicated page shows APU operational status including door position (OPEN/CLOSED), RPM, EGT, oil pressure, oil temperature, and other key parameters. The STATUS page consolidates critical APU information for crew monitoring. The door position is specifically shown as either OPEN or CLOSED on this page.
04APU02.source: FCOM1 - APU System, SmartCockpit A220 APU Documentation
04APU02.page: APU System - EICAS Display and STATUS Synoptic Page

04APU19.explanation: When a critical ECU fault occurs (such as loss of DC power to the ECU), the APU will shut down immediately whether on the ground OR in flight. Critical ECU faults are treated the same in both flight regimes because the ECU can no longer safely control the APU. Without ECU control, the APU cannot be safely operated. This is different from other faults like high oil temperature, which only cause shutdown on ground but not in flight. Critical ECU faults represent a complete loss of APU control capability.
04APU19.source: FCOM1 - APU System, SmartCockpit A220 APU Documentation
04APU19.page: APU System - Critical ECU Fault Shutdown Logic

04APU03.explanation: The ECU commands an APU Built-In Test (BITE) when the APU rotary switch is in the START position for at least 3 seconds. During this time, the ECU performs a self-test to verify all APU systems are functioning properly before initiating the start sequence. The BITE test checks ECU functionality, sensors, and control systems. During the test, 'APU IN BITE' message displays on ED2 (EICAS Display 2). If the BITE test fails, the APU FAIL light illuminates and the start is aborted.
04APU03.source: FCOM1 - APU System, SmartCockpit A220 APU Documentation

04APU17.explanation: The ECU (Electronic Control Unit) is the component that controls and monitors the APU. The ECU provides complete automated control including: start sequence management, shutdown procedures, inlet door positioning, fuel flow control, monitoring of all APU parameters (temperature, pressure, speed), fault detection and protection, and automatic shutdown when necessary. The ECU is the 'brain' of the APU system. Other units mentioned (ECP is not a standard term, PFCC controls flight controls, FCU is Fuel Control Unit which is controlled BY the ECU).
04APU17.source: FCOM1 - APU System, SmartCockpit A220 APU Documentation
04APU17.page: APU System - Electronic Control Unit (ECU) Functions

04APU14.explanation: A failed/slow/hot/hung start will cause the APU to shutdown automatically on the ground OR in flight. These start abnormalities indicate the APU is not starting properly and continuing the start could cause damage. In contrast: low oil pressure causes shutdown on ground only (not in flight), excessive oil temperature causes shutdown on ground only (not in flight), and an APU fire causes automatic shutdown on ground only (not in flight). Failed starts are dangerous in both regimes and warrant immediate shutdown.
04APU14.source: FCOM1 - APU System, SmartCockpit A220 APU Documentation

04APU06.explanation: The APU can be started with three possible power sources: (1) External power - when ground AC power is connected, it powers the aircraft systems including APU start capability, (2) Both aircraft batteries - Battery 1 powers the ECU while Battery 2 powers the starter motor, (3) AC power through Transformer Rectifier Unit 3 (TRU 3) - when AC power is available (from external power or engine generators), TRU 3 converts it to DC for APU start. Battery 1 alone is insufficient - both batteries are needed if using battery power.
04APU06.source: FCOM1 - APU System, SmartCockpit A220 APU Documentation
04APU06.page: APU Operations - Power Source Requirements for Starting

04APU04.explanation: The APU FAIL light illuminates for three conditions: (1) APU fire detection fails on the ground - indicates the fire detection system is not functioning, creating a safety hazard for unattended ground operations, (2) Failed start - indicates the APU did not start properly (slow start, hot start, hung start, or no start), (3) Failure of built-in-test (BITE) - indicates the ECU's self-test detected a fault before starting. Moving the rotary switch to OFF is a normal operation and does NOT illuminate the FAIL light - it's a commanded shutdown.
04APU04.source: FCOM1 - APU System, SmartCockpit A220 APU Documentation
04APU04.page: APU System - FAIL Light Illumination Conditions

04APU13.explanation: When the APU rotary switch is placed to the START position for three seconds, the APU fuel shutoff valve opens. This is part of the start sequence preparation. During these initial 3 seconds, the ECU also performs a BITE test to verify system functionality. After the BITE test completes successfully and the fuel shutoff valve opens, the APU fuel pump is energized, the inlet door opens (on ground), and then the start sequence proceeds. The fuel shutoff valve opening is critical to allow fuel flow to the APU for combustion during start.
04APU13.source: FCOM1 - APU System, SmartCockpit A220 APU Documentation

04APU20.explanation: APU oil quantity, pressure, and temperature values are displayed on the STATUS page (STATUS synoptic page). This page consolidates all APU performance parameters in one location, including oil system parameters, RPM, EGT (exhaust gas temperature), and inlet door position. While there is no dedicated 'APU synoptic page' on the A220, the STATUS page serves as the primary display for APU system monitoring. The HYD page shows hydraulic system information only, and INFO page shows different aircraft information.
04APU20.source: FCOM1 - APU System, SmartCockpit A220 APU Documentation
04APU20.page: APU System - Oil System Parameter Display on STATUS Page

18PWR08.explanation: Oil quantity is displayed in quarts (QTS) for each engine, but it appears in MULTIPLE locations, not only on the STATUS page. On the A220, oil quantity, temperature, and pressure indications are displayed on the EICAS below the EGT indications, as well as on the STATUS page.

18PWR17.explanation: On the A220 EICAS, oil quantity, temperature, and pressure for each engine are displayed together as a group below the EGT (Exhaust Gas Temperature) indications. This provides pilots with a consolidated view of all oil parameters in one location during normal operations.

18PWR01.explanation: On the PW1500G engines used in the A220, the fan inlet cone and cover are continuously de-iced using engine bleed air. This is a passive system that operates automatically whenever the engine is running, preventing ice accumulation on these critical engine components without requiring pilot action or anti-ice system activation.

18PWR21.explanation: The PW1500G engine uses engine bleed air to continuously de-ice the fan inlet cone and cover. This is an automatic, continuous process that doesn't require the anti-ice system to be activated. The warm bleed air prevents ice formation on these components during all phases of engine operation.

18PWR03.explanation: The N2 shaft (high-pressure spool) of the PW1500G engine consists of an eight-stage high-pressure compressor (HPC) and a two-stage high-pressure turbine (HPT). These components are mechanically connected and rotate together as the high-pressure spool. The HPT extracts energy from the hot gases to drive the HPC.

18PWR05.explanation: The main gearbox (accessory gearbox) of the PW1500G engine is mounted on the fan case and drives several critical accessories: Electronic Engine Control (EEC), Hydraulic Pump (provides hydraulic pressure for aircraft systems), and Variable Frequency Generator (VFG) which generates electrical power for the aircraft.

18PWR20.explanation: The Fan Drive Gear System (FDGS) is the unique and defining feature of the PW1500G 'Geared Turbofan' (GTF) engine. This is what makes it a 'geared' turbofan. The FDGS allows the fan to rotate at a different (slower) speed than the low-pressure turbine, optimizing efficiency for both components. This technology is proprietary to Pratt & Whitney's GTF engine family.

18PWR16.explanation: On the A220 EICAS, oil quantity, temperature, and pressure for each engine are displayed together below the EGT (Exhaust Gas Temperature) indications. This location provides pilots with immediate access to all engine oil parameters in a consolidated format during normal operations.

18PWR11.explanation: This accurately describes the thrust reverser operation on the PW1500G engine. When activated, the reverser cowl (sleeve) translates aft. This aft movement mechanically causes blocker doors to rotate into position, blocking the normal rearward fan airflow and redirecting it forward and outward through cascade vanes, creating reverse thrust.

18PWR04.explanation: The Electronic Engine Control (EEC) on the PW1500G has two channels for redundancy (dual-channel architecture ensures continued engine operation if one channel fails), is the major component of the FADEC (the EEC is the 'brain' of the FADEC system), and monitors engine parameters (constantly monitors N1, N2, temperatures, pressures, and other parameters to optimize engine performance).

18PWR10.explanation: On the A220, the TOGA (Takeoff/Go-Around) pushbuttons are located on the side of each thrust lever. This placement allows pilots to easily activate TOGA mode with their thumb while their hand is already on the thrust lever, providing quick and intuitive access during critical flight phases.

18PWR02.explanation: The Fan Drive Gear System (FDGS) in the PW1500G reduces the fan speed to approximately one-third of the N2 (high-pressure spool) speed. This is expressed as a gear ratio of approximately 3:1. The gear system is connected to the N2 shaft, and through this reduction, allows the fan to rotate at its optimal speed while the turbine rotates faster.

18PWR13.explanation: N1 speed (fan speed) is measured by two separate probes for redundancy. This dual-probe arrangement ensures that the EEC continues to receive accurate N1 speed data even if one probe fails. Redundancy in critical engine parameters is essential for continued safe engine operation and is a standard feature in FADEC-controlled engines.

18PWR14.explanation: The statement is false because in the A220's N1 synchronization system, the RIGHT engine acts as the master and the LEFT engine acts as the subordinate (slave). When N1 sync is engaged, the left engine's N1 speed is automatically adjusted to match the right engine's N1 speed, reducing cockpit vibration and noise during cruise flight.

18PWR12.explanation: When thrust reversers are fully deployed on the A220, a green 'REV' icon appears on the N1 gauge on the EICAS for each engine. Green indicates the reversers are properly deployed and locked. This provides clear visual confirmation to the pilots that the thrust reversers are in the correct position for reverse thrust operation.

18PWR19.explanation: The EEC is powered primarily by the PMAG (Permanent Magnet Alternator Generator), which is mechanically driven by the engine and generates power whenever the engine is rotating. This makes the EEC independent of aircraft electrical power during normal operation. If the PMAG fails, the EEC can be powered by the DC ESSENTIAL BUS as a backup.

18PWR09.explanation: The FADEC automatically activates both ignition systems (continuous ignition) during takeoff or landing flight phases (to prevent flameout during critical phases), when cowl anti-ice is activated (the bleed air extraction can affect combustion stability), and when the FADEC detects an engine surge or flameout (to facilitate automatic relight).

18PWR15.explanation: On the EICAS, N2 speed is displayed in white (normal color) when N2 is at or below 100%. This is the normal operating range. If N2 exceeds 100% (which can occur during certain transient conditions or high-power settings), the indication would change to amber to indicate operation above the normal range.

18PWR22.explanation: When the thrust lever is not in the correct position for engine start (should be at idle detent), the FADEC generates the aural message 'THRUST LEVER' to alert the crew. This prevents attempts to start the engine with thrust levers in an incorrect position, which could result in a hot start or other starting anomaly.

18PWR06.explanation: The PMAG (Permanent Magnet Alternator Generator) is an engine-driven generator that provides electrical power to the EEC (Electronic Engine Control) to ensure the engine control system has reliable power independent of aircraft electrical systems, and to the IFPC (Integrated Fuel Pump and Control) to operate the fuel pump and fuel metering system. The PMAG is mechanically driven by the engine accessory gearbox.

18PWR18.explanation: During automatic engine starts on the ground, the EEC commands only one ignition circuit at a time to conserve electrical power and reduce wear on the ignition system. The EEC intelligently alternates between the two ignition circuits (A and B) after each start to ensure equal usage and wear of both systems. This provides redundancy over time while optimizing system resources.

18PWR07.explanation: Pneumatic pressure for starting the PW1500G engines can be supplied from three sources: Engine cross-bleed air (using bleed air from the operating engine to start the other engine), APU (the Auxiliary Power Unit provides bleed air for engine starts), and High-pressure ground cart (external pneumatic ground support equipment provides high-pressure air). Low-pressure ground carts are insufficient for engine starting.

14LDG20.explanation: The LGSCU (Landing Gear and Steering Control Unit) is the dedicated computer that commands and monitors all nosewheel steering functions. The EMAs are actuators that execute commands, while the LGSCU provides the control logic and monitoring. The FBW system provides steering inputs but the LGSCU controls the actual steering system.

14LDG04.explanation: Pressing the guarded GEAR AURAL switch cancels the continuous 'GEAR' warning when attempting to land with gear not down and locked. This action illuminates the CNCL legend on the switch, mutes the aural warning, and displays a GEAR AURAL CNCL status message on the EICAS to inform the crew that the warning has been intentionally cancelled.

14LDG15.explanation: When conditions are safe for towing (parking brake released and nosewheel steering OFF), the system indicates this through two indications: the TOW/NO TOW light indicator on the nose landing gear shows green, and the green TOW legend illuminates on the electrical towing service panel. These visual confirmations ensure ground crew can safely tow the aircraft.

14LDG10.explanation: Fusible plugs are safety devices designed to prevent tire explosion due to overheating. The three fusible plugs on each MLG wheel are designed to melt at approximately 200°C, releasing tire pressure before the tire can fail catastrophically. This temperature threshold provides adequate protection while avoiding false activations during normal hot brake conditions.

14LDG13.explanation: Each landing gear assembly is equipped with 4 proximity sensors to provide redundant position monitoring. These sensors detect and confirm gear position (up and locked, or down and locked) for system safety and to provide accurate indications to the crew on the EICAS and gear position indicators.

14LDG11.explanation: The brake temperature monitoring system monitors TEMPERATURE, not tire pressure. This is a common misconception - while the MLG wheel wells do have a brake temperature monitoring system, tire pressure information is provided by separate tire pressure sensors, not the brake temperature system. Each system serves a distinct function.

14LDG03.explanation: When the guarded ALTN GEAR switch is set to DN position, it initiates the alternate landing gear extension system. This action releases the landing gear uplocks, allowing the gear to free-fall and extend by gravity. Simultaneously, an ALTN GEAR DN status message displays on the EICAS to inform the crew that alternate extension is in progress.

14LDG02.explanation: During normal gear retraction, hydraulic pressure performs three sequential functions: First, it unlocks the downlocks that hold the gear in the extended position. Second, it powers the actuators to pull the main landing gear inward and the nose landing gear forward into the wheel wells. Third, once the gear reaches the up position, hydraulic pressure locks the gear up via uplocks, and then pressure is removed as the mechanical locks hold the gear without continuous hydraulic pressure.

14LDG18.explanation: The derotation function is a braking protection feature that limits braking force after main wheel touchdown when the nose gear is still in the air. This prevents excessive braking that could cause premature or hard nose gear touchdown, ensuring a controlled landing sequence and preventing damage to the nose landing gear.

14LDG14.explanation: During normal landing gear extension, the ALTN GEAR DN advisory message appearing on the EICAS indicates that the automatic dormancy check of the alternate extension system is in progress. This is a normal, automatic test that verifies the alternate gear extension system remains functional and ready for use if needed. It is not an indication of a problem with normal extension.

14LDG21.explanation: The guarded ALTN GEAR switch in the DN position is specifically designed to release the landing gear uplocks, allowing the gear to free-fall and extend by gravity. This is the alternate/emergency extension method used when normal hydraulic extension is not available. The landing gear lever DN position uses normal hydraulic extension, not free-fall.

14LDG16.explanation: The A220 features an advanced electric brake system consisting of electromechanical actuators (EMAs) and carbon brake stacks. This represents a departure from traditional hydraulic brake systems, offering improved efficiency, reduced weight, and better control. The carbon brake stacks provide excellent heat dissipation and wear characteristics.

14LDG08.explanation: In alternate braking mode, no automatic protections are available. This means functions like antiskid, derotation, touchdown protection, and locked wheel protection are all unavailable. Pilots must apply brakes carefully and manually to prevent wheel lockup and maintain directional control, as they would in a conventional brake system without protections.

14LDG07.explanation: Landing gear retraction braking is the specific protection function that automatically stops the main wheels from rotating during gear retraction. This prevents the wheels from spinning in the wheel wells, which could cause damage to the gear, wheel well structure, and surrounding components. The braking is applied automatically as part of the retraction sequence.

14LDG17.explanation: The landing gear retraction sequence on the A220 is designed for optimal aerodynamics and space efficiency. The main landing gear is pulled inward toward the fuselage centerline, while the nose landing gear is pulled forward into the nose wheel well. This retraction pattern allows the gear to fit efficiently into the aircraft structure.

14LDG19.explanation: The A220 features electric brakes on the main landing gear, utilizing electromechanical actuators instead of traditional hydraulic brakes. However, the nose landing gear steering system uses hydraulic pressure (from Hydraulic System 2) to actuate the steering mechanism, providing the force needed to turn the nose wheels during ground operations.

14LDG12.explanation: The antiskid protection system operates across a wide speed range from 10 knots up to 204 knots. Below 10 knots, antiskid is automatically deactivated as wheel speed becomes too slow for effective antiskid operation. The 204-knot upper limit covers all normal landing and rejected takeoff scenarios, providing protection throughout the critical braking phases.

14LDG22.explanation: The autobrake function provides automatic braking in two scenarios: after landing (when armed) and during a rejected takeoff (RTO). When armed and activated, the autobrake system automatically applies brakes at a predetermined rate, allowing the pilot to focus on directional control and other tasks. This is distinct from protection functions like derotation or touchdown protection, which limit or modulate braking force.

14LDG05.explanation: The main landing gear (MLG) is equipped with electric brakes on each wheel, utilizing electromechanical actuators and carbon brake stacks. The system also includes parking brake functionality, which can be engaged to hold the aircraft stationary on the ground. The parking brake works through the electric brake system to maintain brake application without continuous pilot input.

14LDG09.explanation: The autobrake function activates in two primary situations: during a rejected takeoff when speed exceeds 60 kt (with RTO mode armed), and at touchdown during landing (with landing autobrake mode armed). During RTO, the 60-kt threshold ensures autobrake only activates when aircraft speed is high enough to require automated braking assistance. At touchdown, wheel spin-up signals autobrake activation.

14LDG01.explanation: The nosewheel steering system is powered by Hydraulic System No. 2 on the A220. This hydraulic pressure actuates the steering mechanism, providing the force necessary to turn the nose wheels during taxi, takeoff, and landing rollout. The hydraulic system provides reliable, powerful steering control for ground operations.

14LDG06.explanation: Electric brakes are installed on each wheel of the main landing gear. Each MLG wheel has its own electromechanical actuator (EMA) that controls the brake for that specific wheel. This provides independent braking control for each wheel, enabling advanced features like antiskid protection and optimal brake force distribution across all main gear wheels.

21ECL08.explanation: The FCTN (Function) tile on the Electronic Checklist displays a drop-down menu that allows a checklist to be reset or overridden. When selected, this tile provides access to several checklist management functions including: RESET NORMALS (resets all normal checklists to their initial state), RESET ALL (resets all checklists including non-normals), OVERRIDE CHKL (allows the crew to override and bypass an entire checklist), and OVERRIDE ITEM (allows overriding individual checklist items). These functions give pilots the operational flexibility needed to manage checklist states during non-normal operations, when returning to normal operations after resolving issues, or when operational circumstances require deviation from standard checklist flows. The NORMAL, NON-NORMAL, and PROC tiles serve different purposes - they are navigation tiles for accessing different types of checklists, not function management tiles.

sources.page: Electronic Checklist - FCTN Tile Functions and Controls (pages 2161-2177)

21ECL10.explanation: When the Electronic Checklist (ECL) is not available due to system failure, software malfunction, or hardware issues, the message 'CHECKLIST NOT AVAILABLE' displays on the page. This clear, unambiguous indication immediately alerts the flight crew that the ECL system is inoperative and cannot be relied upon for checklist operations. When this message appears, all checklist content is removed from the display to prevent confusion or use of potentially corrupted data. The crew must immediately transition to using paper backup checklists to continue flight operations safely. The other messages listed (OVERRIDDEN, STARTED, COMPLETED) are normal operational status messages that appear during regular ECL use and do not indicate system unavailability.

21ECL02.explanation: The statement is TRUE. When the Electronic Checklist (ECL) system is not available due to a system failure or malfunction, all checklist content is completely removed from the display and the message 'CHECKLIST NOT AVAILABLE' appears on the page. This clearly indicates to the flight crew that the ECL system is inoperative and they must immediately revert to paper checklists. The system completely clears the display rather than showing potentially incomplete or unreliable checklist information, ensuring flight safety. This design prevents crews from relying on a malfunctioning system.

sources.page: Electronic Checklist - System Failures and Unavailability (pages 2161-2177)

21ECL09.explanation: The Electronic Checklist (ECL) displays normal and non-normal checklists and procedures. This comprehensive coverage includes all routine normal checklists for standard flight operations (covering all phases from preflight through securing the aircraft), as well as all non-normal checklists for handling system malfunctions, failures, abnormal situations, and emergency procedures. The ECL provides the complete set of checklists and procedures that are also available in paper format, making it a full electronic replacement for traditional paper checklists while offering enhanced features such as automatic item tracking, status indications, and integrated procedures. It does not display only normal checklists, only non-normal checklists, or checklists not found in paper format - it mirrors the complete paper checklist content.

sources.page: Electronic Checklist - Content Overview and Coverage (pages 2161-2177)

21ECL01.explanation: The OVERRIDE CHKL option in the FCTN (Function) drop-down menu allows pilots to override an entire checklist. This function is available when a checklist needs to be bypassed due to operational requirements or non-normal situations. The FCTN tile provides access to various checklist management functions including OVERRIDE CHKL (override entire checklist), RESET NORMALS (reset all normal checklists), RESET ALL (reset all checklists), and OVERRIDE ITEM (override individual checklist items). The other options listed - OVERRIDE ITEM, RESET ALL, and RESET NORMALS - serve different purposes and do not override the entire checklist.

21ECL03.explanation: When a limitation checklist item has been selected from a normal or non-normal checklist, the limitation displays on the SUMMARY page in two specific ways: (1) The page footer displays 'LIMITATIONS' to indicate that one or more limitations are currently active and need crew attention, and (2) The limitation text appears in the history subsection located below the checklist from which it was originally generated, allowing pilots to trace the limitation back to its source. Limitations do not display in the normal checklists section itself - they have their own dedicated display area. This design ensures pilots can easily review all active limitations in one consolidated location while maintaining context about their origin.

sources.page: Electronic Checklist - SUMMARY Page and Limitations Display (pages 2161-2177)

21ECL05.explanation: The NORMAL page of the Electronic Checklist displays normal checklists for all phases of flight. This page provides centralized access to all standard operating checklists used during routine flight operations, including preflight, before start, after start, before takeoff, climb, cruise, descent, approach, before landing, after landing, parking, and securing checklists. The NORMAL page is one of the four main ECL pages accessible through tiles, along with the SUMMARY page (shows checklist status and history), NON-NORMAL page (displays abnormal and emergency checklists), and PROC page (procedures). Each page serves a distinct function in the ECL system architecture.

21ECL07.explanation: The statement is TRUE. The Electronic Checklist (ECL) does not open automatically and must be manually selected and accessed by the flight crew. While the system may provide automated alerts or indications when certain checklists become applicable or when abnormal conditions occur (triggering automatic checklist presentation), the crew must actively select and open the ECL display application to view and use the checklists. This design philosophy ensures that crews maintain active engagement with checklist procedures and prevents unwanted automatic display changes during critical phases of flight that could distract from primary flight duties. The crew retains full control over when and how they access checklist information.

sources.page: Electronic Checklist - Operation and Access Methods (pages 2161-2177)

21ECL06.explanation: The Electronic Checklist displays three types of notifications with distinct visual formatting to convey different levels of importance: (1) WARNING - not listed in the correct answers but would display in red surrounded by a red box to indicate immediate danger or critical information, (2) CAUTION - displays in white text surrounded by an amber box to indicate situations requiring awareness and possible action to prevent injury or aircraft damage, and (3) NOTE - displays in white text with no surrounding box for general information, clarifications, or helpful reminders. This color coding and formatting hierarchy matches the standard aviation warning system used throughout the flight deck displays and manuals, ensuring consistency and immediate recognition by flight crews.

sources.page: Electronic Checklist - Notifications and Text Formatting (pages 2161-2177)

21ECL04.explanation: The statement is TRUE. The Electronic Checklist (ECL) system displays all normal and non-normal checklists and procedures that are available in the paper checklist format. The ECL is designed to be a complete electronic replacement for paper checklists, providing exactly the same information in an interactive digital format with enhanced functionality. This includes all normal checklists for all flight phases (preflight, before start, after start, before takeoff, after takeoff, climb, cruise, descent, approach, landing, after landing, parking, securing) as well as all non-normal checklists and emergency procedures. The content is identical to the paper version to ensure standardization and regulatory compliance.

sources.page: Electronic Checklist - General Description and Content (pages 2161-2177)

10FCT16.explanation: Ground spoilers operate automatically only in normal mode and PFCC direct mode. In REU direct mode, there is no automatic ground lift dumping function. In AFCU direct mode, multifunction spoilers (MFSs) are not available at all. Therefore, ground spoilers are not available in both AFCU direct mode and REU direct mode.

10FCT21.explanation: The high-lift system consists of slats and flaps. There are four slat panels on each wing and two Fowler-type flaps on each wing. Ailerons and elevators are primary flight controls, not part of the high-lift system.

10FCT17.explanation: Automatic nose-up pitch compensation is provided in a turn for bank angles of up to 33 degrees. Beyond this bank angle, aft sidestick must be applied to maintain flight path. This is part of the pitch compensation in turns function of the FBW normal mode.

10FCT20.explanation: The hydraulic brakes hold the slats and flaps in their commanded positions between selections. They can also stop the motion of the slats/flaps if an abnormal condition is detected, such as asymmetry or uncommanded runaway extension. They do not activate during single motor or hydraulic failures.

10FCT01.explanation: A single PFCC (Primary Flight Control Computer) controls the A220's fly-by-wire system at any given time, with the other two PFCCs serving as hot standby backups ready to take over instantly if needed. The PFCC may be selected off in case of a malfunction using the dedicated PFCC switches on the overhead panel, allowing the crew to deactivate a faulty computer and transfer control to one of the healthy standby units. The three PFCCs do not all actively control the system simultaneously - only one is in command at a time.

sources.page: Flight Controls - Primary Flight Control Computers

10FCT04.explanation: The A220's fly-by-wire (FBW) system commands all primary flight controls (ailerons, elevators, and rudder) as well as specific secondary flight controls. The FBW-commanded secondary controls include the horizontal stabilizer for pitch trim, multifunction spoilers for roll assist and speed braking, and ground spoilers for landing deceleration - but NOT the flaps and slats. The flaps and slats are controlled by a separate conventional system through the Slat Flap Control Computer (SFCC) and are not part of the FBW architecture, as they require different control logic for configuration management.

10FCT07.explanation: The fly-by-wire direct mode has three submodes based on which component is providing the control path: PFCC direct (at least one PFCC available but operating with degraded control laws), REU direct (all PFCCs failed, REUs receiving commands from AFCU but processing them independently), and AFCU direct (complete backup mode with AFCU routing signals directly to individual PCU channels). PCU direct is not a recognized submode - the PCUs are always the final actuators regardless of control mode. Each direct submode represents a progressively more degraded control state with reduced flight envelope protection but maintained controllability.

10FCT30.explanation: Following an engine failure in flight, the engine out compensation provides partial automatic yaw compensation. The rudder is automatically applied to counter the yaw caused by asymmetric thrust. This compensation helps control the aircraft during and after the failure without fully masking the engine failure.

10FCT10.explanation: When the sidestick AP/PTY pushbutton is pressed and held for momentary priority, three key indications occur: the autopilot (if engaged) automatically disconnects to allow manual control, the onside glareshield SIDESTICK switch/light PTY green legend flashes while the opposite side red arrow illuminates (showing priority status), and a "PRIORITY LEFT" or "PRIORITY RIGHT" aural message sounds to alert both pilots. The autopilot does not remain engaged during sidestick priority takeover - it must disconnect to allow the pilot taking priority to have full manual control authority without autopilot interference.

10FCT28.explanation: When spoilers have been manually deployed and a bank requiring roll assist is initiated, the FBW system partially retracts the high-wing multifunction spoilers to assist with the roll. The low-wing spoilers are not retracted; instead, additional deployment may occur on the high wing.

10FCT15.explanation: The horizontal stabilizer (HSTAB) on the A220 is electrically controlled and electrically actuated through two electric motors (no hydraulics involved), making it independent of the hydraulic systems for greater reliability. In fly-by-wire normal mode, the HSTAB is automatically positioned by the PFCCs to maintain the desired pitch attitude and speed, with crew inputs to the pitch trim switches adjusting the target rather than directly moving the stabilizer. However, in fly-by-wire direct mode, the HSTAB reverts to conventional trimming where the pitch trim switches directly command stabilizer movement, requiring the crew to manually trim the aircraft for hands-off flight like in traditional aircraft.

10FCT24.explanation: The Remote Electronic Units (REUs) transmit commands received from the PFCCs to both the hydraulic Power Control Units (PCUs) that move the flight control surfaces and to the HSTAB Motor Control Electronics (MCE) unit that positions the horizontal stabilizer.

10FCT23.explanation: In the FBW system, the Remote Electronic Units (REUs) position the control surfaces through hydraulic actuators (PCUs). The PFCCs compute the commands, but the REUs transmit those commands to the hydraulic actuators that physically move the surfaces.

10FCT05.explanation: In the extremely unlikely event of a total failure of all three Primary Flight Control Computers (PFCCs), the system automatically reverts to a backup control mode. In this mode, pilot inputs from the flight deck controls (sidesticks, rudder pedals, and trim switches) bypass the PFCCs entirely and are routed directly to the Remote Electronic Units (REUs) through the Alternate Flight Control Unit (AFCU). The REUs then command the hydraulic actuators to position the flight control surfaces. This provides a direct mechanical-like control path without computer processing, though with reduced flight envelope protection.

10FCT25.explanation: In the FBW system, the Remote Electronic Units (REUs) position the control surfaces through hydraulic actuators. The REUs receive commands from the PFCCs and transmit them to the Power Control Units (PCUs), which are the hydraulic actuators that physically move the control surfaces.

10FCT18.explanation: Only one PFCC is in control of the FBW system at any given time. Although there are three PFCCs installed in the aircraft (two in the forward equipment bay and one in the mid equipment bay), they do not operate simultaneously. The PFCC in control is automatically selected at power-up.

10FCT27.explanation: The Alternate Flight Control Unit (AFCU) routes signals directly from the flight deck controls to the PCUs or HSTAB MCE units in the event of a failure of the Remote Electronic Units (REUs). This creates the AFCU direct mode, which bypasses the REUs when multiple REU failures occur.

10FCT22.explanation: The maximum altitude with slats/flaps extended is 20,000 feet. This operational limitation ensures the high-lift system operates within its designed envelope and prevents potential structural or system issues at higher altitudes.

10FCT29.explanation: Selecting the ALTN FLAP switch to DPLY (deploy) overrides the SLAT/FLAP lever and deploys the slats and flaps to position 3. When deployed to position 3, the status message ALTN FLAP DPLY is displayed on the EICAS page. Position 3 corresponds to 21 degrees slats and 15 degrees flaps.
